headline: Nvidia suppliers halt H200 output after China blocks chip shipments, FT reports
summary: Suppliers of ​parts for ‌Nvidia's H200 chips ‌have paused production after Chinese customs officials ⁠blocked ‌shipments of the newly ‍approved artificial intelligence processors from ​entering China, ‌the Financial Times reported on Friday, citing two people ⁠with knowledge ​of the ​matter. Reuters could not immediately ‍verify ⁠the report.

content.title: Nvidia suppliers halt H200 output after China blocks chip shipments, FT reports
content.summary: Suppliers of ​parts for ‌Nvidia's H200 chips ‌have paused production after Chinese customs officials ⁠blocked ‌shipments of the newly ‍approved artificial intelligence processors from ​entering China, ‌the Financial Times reported on Friday, citing two people ⁠with knowledge ​of the ​matter. Reuters could not immediately ‍verify ⁠the report.

headline: Digi Power X (TSXV:DGX) Is Up 12.2% After US$20M NVIDIA GPU Bet For AI Cloud Push
summary: Digi Power X Inc. recently agreed to purchase about US$20,000,000 of next-generation NVIDIA B300 GPUs from Supermicro for deployment in its Tier III AI data centers and integration into its NeoCloudz GPU-as-a-Service platform, with initial customer availability targeted for March 2026. This step highlights Digi Power X’s push to build an AI computing services business, aiming to generate recurring infrastructure revenues from enterprise, startup, and research users. Next, we’ll explore how...

headline: Super Micro (SMCI) Is Up 8.2% After New AI Retail Deals And $2B Credit Line News
summary: In early January 2026, Super Micro Computer, Inc. announced collaborations with partners including Everseen, Kinetic Vision, and NVIDIA to deliver AI-powered, edge-based intelligent retail solutions aimed at improving in-store operations and supply chain management. The company also secured a new US$2.00 billion revolving credit facility with JPMorgan and other lenders, adding balance sheet flexibility as it expands AI infrastructure offerings amid growing scrutiny of its margins. headline: TSMC Says 'No More' To Nvidia: Why That Is Intel's Golden Ticket
summary: The AI boom just hit a constraint investors don't talk about enough: you can't ship what you can't build. Demand for AI chips is still surging, but the world's leading foundry, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (NYSE:TSM), or TSMC, is starting to run out of room. That matters — because when supply, not demand, becomes the bottleneck, the entire power structure of the AI trade begins to shift. When The Kingmaker Runs Out Of Capacity According to a report first published by The Information
